prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Nonidentical parties

para.paratext: The Panel has rejected the argument that transfer should not be ordered where the parties are not the same in the various cases. For example, the Panel has ordered the transfer of a case where one of the defendants in that action is not a party to any of the other actions.[1] The Panel later ordered transfer of a tag-along action in that case despite the fact that the new action included a plaintiff who was a defendant in the actions previously transferred.[2]

The necessary element for transfer is common factual issues.[3] If there are common factual issues, then the presence of identical parties in the actions is not necessary.[4] The paucity of common parties in the actions may, however, also result in fewer common factual issues, making it a relevant factor in denying centralization.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Airport Car Rental Antitrust Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 273, 275 (J.P.M.L. 1978).

In re Airport Car Rental Antitrust Litigation, 459 F. Supp. 1006, 1007 (J.P.M.L. 1978). So-called tag-along actions are actions related to actions transferred by the Panel but coming to the Panel's attention after the initial transfer order. The procedures for handling tag-along actions are discussed in § 4:24 and the criteria for ordering transfer of these actions is discussed in chapter 8.

The requirement of common factual issues is discussed in § 5:4. For discussion of how various differences in the actions don't prevent transfer, see In re MLR, LLC, Patent Litigation, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003).

See In re Bank of New York Mellon Corp. Foreign Exchange Transactions Litigation, 857 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Refined Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re “Fine Paper” Antitrust Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 118, 121 (J.P.M.L. 1978), aff'd, 685 F.2d 810 (3d Cir. 1982), cert. denied, 459 U.S. 1156, 103 S. Ct. 801, 74 L. Ed. 2d 1003 (1983).

See In re: National Ass'n for Advancement of Multijurisdiction Practice Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (centralization denied where U.S. Attorney General only common defendant to all actions).
